how to regedit to open json with notepad++

To set Notepad++ as the default editor for JSON files using Regedit, you can follow these steps:

1. Press the Windows key + R to open the Run dialog box.
2. Type "regedit" (without the quotes) and press Enter to open the Registry Editor.
3. In the left pane of the Registry Editor, navigate to HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\.json
4. Right-click on the ".json" key and select "New" > "Key". Name the new key "Shell".
5. Right-click on the "Shell" key and select "New" > "Key". Name the new key "Edit with Notepad++".
6. Right-click on the "Edit with Notepad++" key and select "New" > "Key". Name the new key "command".
7. Double-click on the "(Default)" value in the right pane of the "command" key.
8. Set the value data to: "C:\Program Files\Notepad++\notepad++.exe" "%1"
9. Click OK and close the Registry Editor.

After these steps, you should be able to right-click on a JSON file and select "Edit with Notepad++".

why doesnt regedit have a ctrl-z function

Regedit does not have a Ctrl+Z function by default because Windows Registry is a critical system component that stores configuration settings and other important information. It's essential to ensure that changes made in the registry are accurate and intentional to avoid causing system instability or crashes. Allowing users to undo changes easily with a simple keyboard shortcut like Ctrl+Z could lead to accidental changes, which could be a cause of concern. However, you can make changes to the registry through a third-party application that may have an undo button or keyboard shortcut.
